title: Pricing
description: Pricing plan card component for brochureware conversion. Critical decision-making component implementing marketing psychology patterns (anchoring, decoy effect, loss aversion). Displays plan name, price, features, and CTA with optional badge and strikethrough pricing.

features.description: List of included features (uses Feature List molecule)

badge.description: Badge text for highlighting plan (social proof, urgency)

highlighted.description: Whether this is the recommended plan (visual emphasis)

originalPrice.description: Original price for strikethrough display (shows savings, loss aversion)

id.description: Unique identifier for the pricing card

ariaLabel.description: Accessible label for the pricing card

examples.name: Free
examples.description: Perfect for individuals and small projects

requirements: Pricing card must have accessible label (aria-label)
Price amount must be large and readable (4.5:1 contrast)
CTA button must meet 44px touch target
Keyboard navigation must work for entire card
Focus states must be visible on all interactive elements
notes: Badge should not be the only way to identify the recommended plan
Price must be readable by screen readers
Strikethrough pricing must indicate original vs. current price clearly

responsive.mobile: Single column, remove scale on highlighted plan

darkMode.implementation: Automatic via design tokens and CSS custom properties
notes: Highlighted plan shadow adjusts for dark mode
Savings badge uses different colors in dark mode
All text maintains WCAG AA contrast in both modes

patterns.name: Anchoring
patterns.description: Show expensive plan first to make others seem affordable
patterns.implementation: Order plans from Free → Pro → Enterprise, or Enterprise → Pro → Free
patterns.example: Showing $999/month Enterprise plan makes $49/month Pro seem like a steal

patterns.name: Decoy Effect (Goldilocks Pricing)
patterns.description: Middle plan becomes 'just right' when flanked by cheaper and more expensive options
patterns.implementation: Create 3 plans where middle plan offers best value

patterns.name: Loss Aversion
patterns.description: Strikethrough pricing shows what customers are 'saving'
patterns.implementation: Use originalPrice + savings props to show crossed-out price
patterns.example: ~~$79~~ $49/month (Save 38%) makes discount feel like avoiding a loss

patterns.name: Social Proof
patterns.description: Badge guides decision-making ('Most Popular' plan feels safe)
patterns.implementation: Use badge prop on recommended plan
patterns.example: 'Most Popular' badge on Pro plan increases conversion by 20-30%

patterns.name: Friction Reduction
patterns.description: Remove barriers to signup ('No credit card required')
patterns.implementation: Use ctaNote prop below CTA button
patterns.example: '14-day free trial' or 'Cancel anytime' reduces signup anxiety

patterns.name: Price Anchoring (Annual vs. Monthly)
patterns.description: Show annual savings to encourage longer commitment
patterns.implementation: Display monthly price with 'Save 20% with annual billing'

conversionOptimization.implementation: Set highlighted: true on middle-tier plan

conversionOptimization.impact: Left-to-right vs. center focus changes behavior
conversionOptimization.implementation: Desktop: Cheap → Mid → Expensive (or center highlighted plan)

conversionOptimization.impact: 'Start Free Trial' converts better than 'Sign Up'
conversionOptimization.implementation: Use action-oriented CTA text: 'Get Started', 'Try for Free'

conversionOptimization.impact: 'Limited Time' badge can increase urgency, but use authentically
conversionOptimization.implementation: Only use urgency badges for genuine promotions

abTestingRecommendations: Test highlighted plan (left vs. center vs. right position)
Test CTA wording ('Get Started' vs. 'Start Free Trial' vs. 'Sign Up')
Test badge text ('Most Popular' vs. 'Best Value' vs. 'Recommended')
Test strikethrough pricing (with vs. without savings badge)
Test annual vs. monthly pricing toggle
Test number of features shown (5-7 is optimal, more causes choice paralysis)
Test feature order (most valuable features first)
Test pricing order (ascending vs. descending price)

pricing.notes: Keep pricing simple and easy to understand at a glance

features.notes: Be specific and benefit-focused. Lead with most valuable features.

realWorldExamples.strategy: Free, Plus, Business, Enterprise. Monthly/annual toggle. 'Most popular' badge on Plus.
realWorldExamples.conversion: Highlight + annual discount + free trial = high conversion

realWorldExamples.strategy: Per-user pricing calculator, comparison table, 'Most popular' on Pro.
Simple 2-tier (Pay as you go, Custom). Contact Sales for Enterprise.
realWorldExamples.conversion: Simplicity reduces choice paralysis for SMB segment

realWorldExamples.strategy: Free, Team, Enterprise. Focus on Free tier to build user base.
realWorldExamples.conversion: Generous free tier = massive user growth, upsell later
